case_name: Khandesh Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Limited v. Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No.257 of 1958 is an appeal by special leave from the Award dated August 20, 1957, of the Industrial Court, Bombay, in Reference IC No. 197 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.257 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated August 20, 1957, of the Industrial Court, Bombay, in Reference  IC  No. 197 of 1956. K. Daphtary Solicitor - General of India.S. N. Andley, J. Dadachanji and Rameshwar Nath,for the appellant.

facts.text: The appellant is Khandesh Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Limited, a textile mill with factory at Jalgaon.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Khandesh Spinning and Weaving Mills Company Limited, is a textile mill and its factory is situate at Jalgaon. The respondent, Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh, represents the employees of the appellant-Company.

facts.text: The respondent Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh represents the employees of the appellant-Company.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh, represents the employees of the appellant-Company. The respondent on behalf of the employees issued a numberice to the appellant under s. 42 2  of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, demanding payment of reasonable bonus for the period from January 1, 1955 to -December 31, 1955.

facts.text: The respondent issued a notice to the appellant under s. 42(2) of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, demanding payment of reasonable bonus for the period from January 1, 1955 to December 31, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent on behalf of the employees issued a numberice to the appellant under s. 42 2  of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, demanding payment of reasonable bonus for the period from January 1, 1955 to -December 31, 1955. Negotiations in this regard having failed, the respondent made a reference to the Industrial Court under s. 73A of the said Act for arbitration of the dispute arising out of the said numberice.

facts.text: Negotiations regarding the bonus demand failed.

anchor.surface_text: Negotiations in this regard having failed, the respondent made a reference to the Industrial Court under s. 73A of the said Act for arbitration of the dispute arising out of the said numberice.

facts.text: The respondent made a reference to the Industrial Court under s. 73A of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946 for arbitration of the dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Negotiations in this regard having failed, the respondent made a reference to the Industrial Court under s. 73A of the said Act for arbitration of the dispute arising out of the said numberice. The arbitrator, i.e. the Industrial Court, following the Fall Bench Formula, ascertained the surplus to be Rs. 2.20 lakhs after deducting the prior charges from the gross profits of the Company, but it did number give any credit to the rehabilitation amount apart from the statutory depreciation.

facts.text: The Industrial Court, following the Full Bench Formula, ascertained the surplus to be Rs. 2.20 lakhs after deducting prior charges from gross profits.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator, i.e. the Industrial Court, following the Fall Bench Formula, ascertained the surplus to be Rs. 2.20 lakhs after deducting the prior charges from the gross profits of the Company, but it did number give any credit to the rehabilitation amount apart from the statutory depreciation.

facts.text: The Industrial Court did not give credit to rehabilitation amount apart from statutory depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator, i.e. the Industrial Court, following the Fall Bench Formula, ascertained the surplus to be Rs. 2.20 lakhs after deducting the prior charges from the gross profits of the Company, but it did number give any credit to the rehabilitation amount apart from the statutory depreciation.

facts.text: The Industrial Court estimated the amount required for rehabilitation at Rs. 60 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court disallowed this item for the following reasons It estimated the amount required for rehabilitation at Rs. 60 lakhs out of this amount it deducted Rs. 51 lakhs representing tile reserves and the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over a period of 15 years gave the figure of Rs. 60,000 as the amount that should be set apart for the year in question for rehabilitation.

facts.text: The Industrial Court deducted Rs. 51 lakhs representing reserves from the Rs. 60 lakhs rehabilitation amount.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court disallowed this item for the following reasons It estimated the amount required for rehabilitation at Rs. 60 lakhs out of this amount it deducted Rs. 51 lakhs representing tile reserves and the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over a period of 15 years gave the figure of Rs. 60,000 as the amount that should be set apart for the year in question for rehabilitation.

facts.text: The balance of Rs. 9 lakhs for rehabilitation spread over 15 years gave Rs. 60,000 for the year in question.

anchor.surface_text: out of this amount it deducted Rs. 51 lakhs representing tile reserves and the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over a period of 15 years gave the figure of Rs. 60,000 as the amount that should be set apart for the year in question for rehabilitation. As the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, it came to the companyclusion that the Company would number be entitled to any allocation as a prior charge for rehabilitation.

facts.text: Statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639.

anchor.surface_text: As the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, it came to the companyclusion that the Company would number be entitled to any allocation as a prior charge for rehabilitation. After excluding the said item of rehabilitation, it The fixed the surplus in a sum of Rs. 2.20 lakbs and awarded to the employees four months basic wages as bonus.

facts.text: The Industrial Court fixed surplus at Rs. 2.20 lakhs and awarded four months basic wages as bonus to employees.

anchor.surface_text: After excluding the said item of rehabilitation, it The fixed the surplus in a sum of Rs. 2.20 lakbs and awarded to the employees four months basic wages as bonus. The learned Solicitor General companytended that the Industrial Court accepted the position that the reserves were used as working capital, but deducted the said amount from the amount required for rehabilitation on a wrong and unjustified assumption that, as the amounts so required would be spent for rehabilitation over a companyrse of 15 years by instalments, the temporary user of the said reserves would number affect the question as they would be released in part or in whole in future years.

facts.text: The Industrial Court assumed that reserves were used as working capital until spent on rehabilitation.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court in dealing with the companytentions of the parties before it observed as follows It is true that until some amount is required to be spent for rehabilitation, replacement or modernization, reserves must be used as working capital, but Shri Vimadalals argument overlooks that the amount required to be spent for rehabilitation over a companyrse of 15 years is number required to be spent all at once, but by installments over a long period.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the Industrial Court did not record a finding that reserves were used as working capital, only an assumption.

anchor.surface_text: These observations did number record any finding that the reserves were used as working capital. It was only an assumption made by the Industrial Court, as, the view taken by it, it was immaterial whether the reserves were used as working capital or number.

facts.text: The appellant did not prove by evidence that reserves were used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: This result does number advance the case of the appellant unless it is able to prove by admissible evidence that it has used the reserves as working capital during the bonus year in question.

facts.text: No specific allegation in appellant's written statement before Industrial Court that reserves were utilised as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: In the written- statement filed by the appellant before the Industrial Court, numberspecific allegation is made that the reserves were utilised as working capital, though in its statement of calculations the said reserves were number excluded from the amount claimed towards rehabilitation.

facts.text: The General Superintendent of the appellant-Company did not depose that reserves were used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: Strong reliance is placed upon the evidence of the General Superintendent of the appellant-Company, but a perusal of that evidence discloses that the said witness has number deposed that the Company used the reserves as working capital number does the said witness seek to prove either the balancesheet or any extract taken therefrom.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that Rs. 51 lakhs reserves were not used as working capital and rightly deducted by Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs rehabilitation.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons, we have numberoption but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were number used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on January 22, 1960 by SUBBA RAO J.

anchor.surface_text: N. Shroff, for Interveners Nos. 1 and 2. The Intervener No. 3 did number appear. 1960 January 22, The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO J.-This appeal raises the question as to what extent the reserves can be deducted from the amount required for rehabilitation of plant and machinery and also as to the manner by which the deductible reserves can be ascertained.

facts.text: Balance-sheet was not proved by a competent person to show reserves used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: We have already pointed out that the balance-sheet, without its being proved by a person companypetent to do so, cannot prove that any reserves have been utilised as working capital.

facts.text: Respondent did not accept that reserve funds were utilised as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: As there is numberspecific allegation, the respondent also in its statement did number deny the said fact, but in its statement of calculations it did number deduct the reserves from the rehabilitation amount. Therefore, it must be held that the respondent did number accept the position that the reserve funds were utilised as working capital.

facts.text: Intervener No. 3 did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: N. Shroff, for Interveners Nos. 1 and 2. The Intervener No. 3 did number appear. 1960 January 22, The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO J.-This appeal raises the question as to what extent the reserves can be deducted from the amount required for rehabilitation of plant and machinery and also as to the manner by which the deductible reserves can be ascertained.

issues.text: This appeal raises the question as to what extent the reserves can be deducted from the amount required for rehabilitation of plant and machinery and also as to the manner by which the deductible reserves can be ascertained.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal raises the question as to what extent the reserves can be deducted from the amount required for rehabilitation of plant and machinery and also as to the manner by which the deductible reserves can be ascertained. It would be enough if we narrated only the facts relevant to the question raised.

issues.text: what is the scope of the finding of the Industrial Court in this regard ?

anchor.surface_text: The first ques- tion, therefore, is, what is the scope of the finding of the Industrial Court in this regard ? The Industrial Court in dealing with the contentions of the parties before it observed as follows It is true that until some amount is required to be spent for rehabilitation, replacement or modernization, reserves must be used as working capital,

issues.text: whether the reserves were used as working capital

anchor.surface_text: otherwise it will lead to the anomaly of the reserves being excluded from the amount required for rehabilitation, though as a matter of fact the entire reserves were utilised as working capital, and though in future years they were expected to be released but in fact not so released. This would lead to a result inconsistent with the decisions on the subject which have clearly laid down that the reserves which have been used as working capital shall not be deducted from the amount fixed for rehabilitation.

issues.text: What is the procedure to be followed for ascertaining the said facts ?

anchor.surface_text: The reserves may be of two Kinds. Moneys may be set apart by a company to meet future payments which the company is under a contractual or statutory obligation to meet, such as gratuity etc. These amounts are set apart and tied down for a specific purpose and, therefore, they are not available to the employer for rehabilitation purposes.

issues.text: The burden is obviously on the employer who claims the exclusion of the reserves from the rehabilitation amount on the ground that they are used as working capital or reasonably earmarked for a specific purpose

anchor.surface_text: The burden is obviously on the employer who claims the exclusion of the reserves from the rehabilitation amount on the ground that they are used as working capital or reasonably earmarked for a specific purpose to establish the said facts and to prove the same by relevant and acceptable evidence.

issues.text: whether the balance-sheet, without its being proved by a person competent to do so, cannot prove that any reserves have been utilised as working capital

arguments.claim: Industrial Court accepted that reserves were used as working capital but deducted them from rehabilitation amount on wrong assumption about 15-year instalments

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor General contended that the Industrial Court accepted the position that the reserves were used as working capital, but deducted the said amount from the amount required for rehabilitation on a wrong and unjustified assumption that, as the amounts so required would be spent for rehabilitation over a course of 15 years by instalments, the temporary user of the said reserves would not affect the question as they would be released in part or in whole in future years.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t proved by relevant and acceptable evidence that the reserves were so utilised and that it did number place before the Industrial Court any such evid

arguments.court_reasoning: No finding recorded, only assumption; immaterial in IC's view

arguments.claim: Assumption contrary to decided cases and principle governing ascertainment of rehabilitation amount

anchor.surface_text: He argued that this assumption was contrary to the view expressed in decided cases and also the principle governing the ascertainment of the amount for rehabilitation purposes.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e Industrial Court is sound. In ascertaining the surplus for the purpose of fixing the bonus for a particular year, the state of affairs in that year

arguments.court_reasoning: IC opinion unsound; leads to anomaly inconsistent with decisions

arguments.claim: Industrial Court only assumed reserves utilised as working capital; immaterial whether so utilised; appellant must prove by evidence, which it did not

anchor.surface_text: On the contrary the learned counsel for the respondent argued that the Industrial Court only assumed that the reserves had been utilised as working capital, as in the view taken by it did not in the least matter whether the reserves were so utilised or not and that, even if that view was wrong, the appellant could not succeed, unless it proved by relevant and acceptable evidence that the reserves were so utilised and that it did not place before the Industrial Court any such evidence to prove that fact.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: se of the appellant unless it is able to prove by admissible evidence that it has used the reserves as working capital during the bonus year in questi

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellant failed to prove by admissible evidence

arguments.claim: Until amount spent for rehabilitation, reserves must be used as working capital, but amount over 15 years spent by instalments

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court in dealing with the contentions of the parties before it observed as follows It is true that until some amount is required to be spent for rehabilitation, replacement or modernization, reserves must be used as working capital, but Shri Vimadalals argument overlooks that the amount required to be spent for rehabilitation over a course of 15 years is not required to be spent all at once, but by installments over a long period.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d to be spent for rehabilitation over a companyrse of 15 years is number required to be spent all at once, but by installments over a long period. The

arguments.court_reasoning: Opinion unsound; consider state of affairs in bonus year only

arguments.claim: Industrial Court observations only assumption, not finding that reserves used as working capital

anchor.surface_text: These observations did not record any finding that the reserves were used as working capital. It was only an assumption made by the Industrial Court, as, the view taken by it, it was immaterial whether the reserves were used as working capital or not.

arguments.claim: Industrial Court opinion unsound; surplus based on state of affairs in bonus year; future releases considered in future

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the aforesaid opinion expressed by the Industrial Court is sound. In ascertaining the surplus for the purpose of fixing the bonus for a particular year, the state of affairs in that year is the guiding factor. If in a subsequent year any part of the reserves used as working capital is released, that amount will have to be taken into account in ascertaining the surplus for that year and so on for subsequent years otherwise it will lead to the anomaly

arguments.claim: Reserves used as working capital shall not be deducted from rehabilitation amount

anchor.surface_text: This would lead to a result inconsistent with the decisions on the subject which have clearly laid down that the reserves which have been used as working capital shall not be deducted from the amount fixed for rehabilitation.

arguments.claim: Appellant must prove by admissible evidence that reserves used as working capital in bonus year

anchor.surface_text: This result does not advance the case of the appellant unless it is able to prove by admissible evidence that it has used the reserves as working capital during the bonus year in question.

arguments.claim: From Associated Cement: deduct depreciation, general reserves available, not reasonably earmarked reserves, prior rehab allowances

anchor.surface_text: This Court in The Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. Its Workmen restated the principle thus at p. 970 Before actually awarding an appropriate amount in respect of rehabilitation for the bonus year certain deductions have to be made. The first deduction is made on account of the breakdown value of the plant and machinery which is usually calculated at the rate of 50% of the cost price of the block in question. Then the depreciation and general reserves available to the employer are deducted.

arguments.claim: General reserves cannot be deducted if used as working capital

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that by using the said words this Court meant to depart from the well-recognized principle that if the general reserves have not been used as working capital, they cannot be deducted from the rehabilitation amount.

arguments.claim: Reserves of two kinds: tied down for specific contractual/statutory obligations not available for rehab; general reserves available unless used as WC

anchor.surface_text: The reserves may be of two Kinds. Moneys may be set apart by a company to meet future payments which the company is under a contractual or statutory obligation to meet, such as gratuity etc. These amounts are set apart and tied down for a specific purpose and, therefore, they are not available to the employer for rehabilitation purposes. But the same thing cannot be said of the general reserves they would be available to the employer unless he has used them as Working capital.

arguments.claim: Earmarking must be reasonable, not device to reduce bonus; IC to ascertain

anchor.surface_text: The use of the words reasonably earmarked is also deliberate and significant. The mere nominal allocation for binding purposes, such as gratuity etc., in the companys books is not enough. It must be ascertained by the Industrial Court on the material placed before it whether the said amount is far in excess of the requirements of the particular purpose for which it is so earmarked and whether it is only a device to reduce the claim of the labour for bonus.

arguments.claim: Burden on employer to prove reserves used as WC or reasonably earmarked

anchor.surface_text: The burden is obviously on the employer who claims the exclusion of the reserves from the rehabilitation amount on the ground that they are used as working capital or reasonably earmarked for a specific purpose to establish the said facts and to prove the same by relevant and acceptable evidence.

arguments.claim: Industrial Courts should insist on proof, give opportunity to labour; follow s118 BIRA and Order XIX CPC
Balance-sheet not proved by competent person cannot prove reserves used as WC

anchor.surface_text: We have already pointed out that the balance-sheet, without its being proved by a person competent to do so, cannot prove that any reserves have been utilised as working capital.

arguments.claim: No specific allegation in written statement that reserves utilised as WC

anchor.surface_text: In the written-statement filed by the appellant before the Industrial Court, no specific allegation is made that the reserves were utilised as working capital, though in its statement of calculations the said reserves were not excluded from the amount claimed towards rehabilitation.

arguments.claim: Respondent did not accept reserves used as WC

anchor.surface_text: As there is no specific allegation, the respondent also in its statement did not deny the said fact, but in its statement of calculations it did not deduct the reserves from the rehabilitation amount. Therefore, it must be held that the respondent did not accept the position that the reserve funds were utilised as working capital.

arguments.claim: General Superintendent did not depose reserves used as WC or prove balance-sheet

anchor.surface_text: Strong reliance is placed upon the evidence of the General Superintendent of the appellant-Company, but a perusal of that evidence discloses that the said witness has not deposed that the Company used the reserves as working capital nor does the said witness seek to prove either the balance-sheet or any extract taken therefrom.

arguments.claim: Rs 51 lakhs reserves not used as WC, rightly deducted from Rs 60 lakhs rehab

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons, we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation.

holdings.text: The Industrial Court's observations did not record any finding that the reserves were used as working capital; it was only an assumption as it was immaterial in its view.

anchor.surface_text: These observations did number record any finding that the reserves were used as working capital. It was only an assumption made by the Industrial Court, as, the view taken by it, it was immaterial whether the reserves were used as working capital or number.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual analysis of IC's words shows no explicit finding, only hypothetical assumption since immaterial to its reasoning.

holdings.text: The Industrial Court's opinion that reserves temporarily used until instalment spending does not affect deduction is unsound; surplus ascertained based on bonus year's state, future releases considered later.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the aforesaid opinion expressed by the Industrial Court is sound. In ascertaining the surplus for the purpose of fixing the bonus for a particular year, the state of affairs in that year is the guiding factor. If in a subsequent year any part of the reserves used as working capital is released, that amount will have to be taken into account in ascertaining the surplus for that year and so on for subsequent years otherwise it will lead to the anomaly

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies principle of year-specific surplus calculation; avoids anomaly of inconsistent treatment across years.

holdings.text: Reserves used as working capital shall not be deducted from the amount fixed for rehabilitation.

anchor.surface_text: This would lead to a result inconsistent with the decisions on the subject which have clearly laid down that the reserves which have been used as working capital shall number be deducted from the amount fixed for rehabilitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows settled decisions; IC view inconsistent therewith.

holdings.text: The employer must prove by admissible evidence that reserves have been used as working capital during the bonus year.

anchor.surface_text: This result does number advance the case of the appellant unless it is able to prove by admissible evidence that it has used the reserves as working capital during the bonus year in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary for employer to establish claim for exclusion; no proof advances no case.

holdings.text: General reserves available to employer are deductible from rehabilitation amount unless used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that by using the said words this Court meant to depart from the well- recognized principle that if the general reserves have number been used as working capital, they cannot be deducted from the rehabilitation amount.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets Associated Cement; reaffirms well-recognized principle.

holdings.text: Reserves are of two kinds: those tied for contractual/statutory obligations not available for rehabilitation; general reserves available unless used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: The reserves may be of two Kinds. Moneys may be set apart by a companypany to meet future payments which the companypany is under a companytractual or statutory obligation to meet, such as gratuity etc. These amounts are set apart and tied down for a specific purpose and, therefore, they are number available to the employer for rehabilitation purposes. But the same thing cannot be said of the general reserves they would be available to the employer unless he his used them as Working capital.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Categorizes reserves logically; aligns with prior principles.

holdings.text: Reserves reasonably earmarked for specific purposes deductible only if not excess or device to reduce bonus; Industrial Court to ascertain on evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The use of the words reasonably earmarked is also deliberate and significant. The mere numberinal allocation for binding purposes, such as gratuity etc., in the companypanys books is Dot enough. It must be ascertained by the Industrial Court on the material placed before it whether the said amount is far in excess of the requirements of the particular purpose for which it is so earmarked and whether it is only a device to reduce the claim of the labour for bonus.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive reading of 'reasonably earmarked'; prevents abuse.

holdings.text: Burden on employer claiming exclusion of reserves from rehabilitation to prove use as working capital or reasonable earmarking by relevant acceptable evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The burden is obviously on the employer who claims the exclusion of the reserves from the rehabilitation amount on the ground that they are used as working capital or reasonably earmarked for a specific purpose to establish the said facts and to prove the same by relevant and acceptable evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical placement of burden on claimant; equity demands proof.

holdings.text: Industrial Courts should insist on proper proof of rehabilitation items, afford cross-examination opportunity, follow s.118 BIRA and Order XIX CPC procedure using affidavits where appropriate.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies statutory powers and CPC; natural justice for disputed figures.

holdings.text: Balance-sheet without proof by competent witness cannot establish reserves used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: We have already pointed out that the balance-sheet, without its being proved by a person companypetent to do so, cannot prove that any reserves have been utilised as working capital.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard evidence rule; unproved document insufficient.

holdings.text: Rs. 51 lakhs reserves were not used as working capital; rightly deducted by Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs rehabilitation amount.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons, we have numberoption but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were number used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No specific allegation, no proof via witness or balance-sheet, respondent non-acceptance; applies burden and evidence rules.

holdings.text: Industrial Court rightly excluded entire rehabilitation amount as annual figure Rs. 60,000 less than statutory depreciation Rs. 83,639.

anchor.surface_text: As the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over 15 years came to only Rs. 60,000 during the bonus year and as the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus.

precedents.citation: The Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. It,3 Workmen 1 1959 S.C.R. 925

anchor.surface_text: The Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. It,3 Workmen 1 1959 S.C.R. 925

precedents.case_name: Associated Cement Companies Ltd v Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Deductions from rehabilitation amount: breakdown value of plant at 50% of cost, depreciation and general liquid reserves available to employer; reserves reasonably earmarked for specific purposes of industry not deducted; prior rehabilitation amounts if available and unused deducted
precedents.cited_holding: Before actually awarding an appropriate amount in respect of rehabilitation for the bonus year certain deductions have to be made. The first deduction is made on account of the breakdown value of the plant and machinery which is usually calculated at the rate of 50/ of the cost price of the block in question. Then the depreciation and general liquid reserves available to the employer are deducted. The reserves which have already been reasonably earmarked for specific purposes of the industry are, however, not taken into account in this connection.

precedents.citation: The Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. Its Workmen 1 1959 S.C.R. 925

anchor.surface_text: The Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. Its Workmen 1 1959 S.C.R. 925

precedents.case_name: Associated Cement Companies Ltd v Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Items declared to have prior charge over bonus deducted from gross profits

precedents.citation: lndian Hume Pipe Company Ltd v. Their workmen 1 1959 S.C,R. 92,5

anchor.surface_text: lndian Hume Pipe Company Ltd v. Their workmen 1 1959 S.C,R. 92,5

precedents.case_name: Indian Hume Pipe Company Ltd v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Balance-sheet can prove reserves available and used as working capital if no objection raised by tribunal
precedents.cited_holding: the balance-sheet was relied upon for proving that the amounts were available for use as working capital and that the balance-sheet showed that they were in fact so used. Moreover, no objection was urged in this behalf, nor was any finding to the contrary recorded by the tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons, we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation. As the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over 15 years came to only Rs. 60,000 during the bonus year and as the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus.

anchor.surface_text: These observations did number record any finding that the reserves were used as working capital. It was only an assumption made by the Industrial Court, as, the view taken by it, it was immaterial whether the reserves were used as working capital or number.

For the aforesaid reasons, we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation. As the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over 15 years came to only Rs. 60,000 during the bonus year and as the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the aforesaid opinion expressed by the Industrial Court is sound. In ascertaining the surplus for the purpose of fixing the bonus for a particular year, the state of affairs in that year is the guiding factor. If in a subsequent year any part of the reserves used as working capital is released, that amount will have to be taken into account in ascertaining the surplus for that year and so on for subsequent years otherwise it will lead to the anomaly

For the aforesaid reasons, we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation. anchor.surface_text: This would lead to a result inconsistent with the decisions on the subject which have clearly laid down that the reserves which have been used as working capital shall number be deducted from the amount fixed for rehabilitation.

For the aforesaid reasons, we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation. As the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over 15 years came to only Rs. 60,000 during the bonus year and as the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus.
This result does number advance the case of the appellant unless it is able to prove by admissible evidence that it has used the reserves as working capital during the bonus year in question.

anchor.surface_text: The reserves may be of two Kinds. Moneys may be set apart by a companypany to meet future payments which the companypany is under a companytractual or statutory obligation to meet, such as gratuity etc. These amounts are set apart and tied down for a specific purpose and, therefore, they are number available to the employer for rehabilitation purposes. But the same thing cannot be said of the general reserves they would be available to the employer unless he his used them as Working capital.

For the aforesaid reasons, we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation. As the balance of Rs. 9 lakhs spread over 15 years came to only Rs. 60,000 during the bonus year and as the statutory depreciation was Rs. 83,639, the Industrial Court rightly excluded the entire rehabilitation amount from its calculations in arriving at the surplus.

anchor.surface_text: The use of the words reasonably earmarked is also deliberate and significant. The mere numberinal allocation for binding purposes, such as gratuity etc., in the companypanys books is Dot enough. It must be ascertained by the Industrial Court on the material placed before it whether the said amount is far in excess of the requirements of the particular purpose for which it is so earmarked and whether it is only a device to reduce the claim of the labour for bonus.

For the aforesaid reasons, we have no option but to hold that Rs. 51 lakhs representing the reserves were not used as working capital and, therefore, the said amount was rightly deducted by the Industrial Court from Rs. 60 lakhs fixed by it towards rehabilitation.
